topics.title: Per-90 normalization
topics.description: Compare players fairly by adjusting totals to a per-90 minute rate.
topics.summary: Per-90 rates let you compare output when players have different minutes, roles, or match availability.
takeaways: Use per-90 to compare players who played very different minutes.
Pair per-90 with totals so you understand both rate and workload.
Look for supporting context like role and team style before drawing conclusions.

sections.title: Why it matters
body: Raw totals can be misleading when one player has twice the minutes of another.
Per-90 rates normalize outputs to a full-match basis, helping you compare roles and production fairly.

sections.title: How to interpret
body: If a player has high per-90 output but low minutes, look at consistency and recent starts.
If a player has high totals but lower per-90, they may be volume-dependent or play more minutes than peers.

faq.q: Is per-90 always better than totals?
faq.a: Per-90 is best for comparing rates, but totals still matter for understanding workload and durability. Use both together.
There is no fixed rule, but rates stabilize more when minutes are higher. Use context like starts, role, and recent minutes.

topics.title: Efficiency vs volume
topics.description: Balance how often a player shoots with how often those shots turn into goals.
topics.summary: Great output can come from high volume, elite efficiency, or both. Learn to separate them.
takeaways: Volume signals opportunity; efficiency signals conversion quality.
Avoid overvaluing small-sample efficiency without consistent volume.
Compare players within similar roles to avoid misleading extremes.

sections.title: Spotting volume
body: Shots/90 and touches in the box highlight players who generate chances frequently.
High volume without finishing may still be valuable if it keeps pressure on opponents.

sections.title: Reading efficiency
body: Goals per shot and shot accuracy show how well a player converts chances.
Efficiency spikes can be volatile, so check multiple seasons or similar-minute samples.

faq.q: What if a player is low volume but high efficiency?
faq.a: That can indicate elite finishing or a small sample. Look at minutes and role before projecting future output.

topics.title: Reading a comparison
topics.description: Break down head-to-head comparisons without overreacting to one metric.
topics.summary: Use comparison outputs as a learning brief: rate, efficiency, and role context in one view.
takeaways: Start with minutes and per-90 rates to normalize differences.
Check efficiency next, then interpret with team and role context.
Use comparisons for discussion, not prediction.

sections.title: Start with the baseline
body: Always open with minutes played and per-90 outputs before scanning totals.
Comparing like-for-like roles reduces noise in the results.

sections.title: Layer in context
body: Team style, position, and tactical role can change how stats show up.
If two players have similar per-90 rates, context can explain the differences in totals.

faq.q: Can I use comparisons to predict results?
faq.a: No. Comparisons are educational and should be used as a discussion tool, not as a prediction engine.

topics.title: Minutes and role context
topics.description: Understand how playing time and tactical role influence every stat.
topics.summary: Minutes and role determine opportunity. Context tells you if a rate is sustainable.
takeaways: Minutes show reliability and coaching trust.
Role explains why similar players have different outputs.
Context helps avoid unfair comparisons across positions.

sections.title: Why minutes matter
body: High totals can be a product of heavy minutes rather than elite efficiency.
Low minutes may hide upside or reflect role limitations.

sections.title: Role-driven output
body: A pressing winger and a target striker will generate different stat profiles.
Use roles to explain trade-offs instead of declaring one player better.

faq.q: Should I ignore a player with low minutes?
faq.a: Not necessarily. Look for recent trend lines, injuries, or tactical changes that explain the minutes.

topics.title: Building comparison briefs
topics.description: Turn a comparison into a short, shareable insight summary.
topics.summary: Use a structured brief to summarize a comparison for scouting notes or team discussions.
takeaways: Summarize rate, efficiency, and role in three short bullets.
Call out one key advantage and one caution for each player.
Link back to the comparison for transparency.

sections.title: Brief structure
body: Start with a one-line overview of the players being compared.
Add three bullets: rate highlight, efficiency highlight, and role context.

sections.title: Sharing responsibly
body: Always label comparisons as educational and non-predictive.
Include the compare link so others can verify the numbers.

faq.q: Where should I share a brief?
faq.a: Use internal channels or discussions with scouts, analysts, or fans. Avoid presenting it as a prediction or betting advice.
